evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Defendants have taken a series of actions to terminate IES’s performance of statutorily required functions.

extracted.value: Defendants have taken a series of actions to terminate IES’s performance of statutorily required functions.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Since February 2025, Defendants have taken a series of actions to terminate IES’s performance of statutorily required functions.

extracted.value: Since February 2025, Defendants have taken a series of actions to terminate IES’s performance of statutorily required functions.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: On February 10, 2025, IES employees were informed that employees of the so‑called “Department of Government Efficiency” had made the decision to cancel most of IES’s contracts and begun the process to do so.

extracted.value: On February 10, 2025, IES employees were informed that employees of the so‑called “Department of Government Efficiency” had made the decision to cancel most of IES’s contracts and begun the process to do so.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: DOGE subsequently announced this decision on its X account, and has since posted on its “Wall of Receipts” website that approximately 90 IES contracts were canceled on February 10 or 11, 2025—including contracts for research activities and contracts that allowed for the basic functioning of IES.

extracted.value: DOGE subsequently announced this decision on its X account, and has since posted on its “Wall of Receipts” website that approximately 90 IES contracts were canceled on February 10 or 11, 2025—including contracts for research activities and contracts that allowed for the basic functioning of IES.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated the contract for the High School and Beyond Longitudinal Study of 2020, which was shifted to 2022 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and had already begun to produce valuable data for researchers.

extracted.value: ED terminated the contract for the High School and Beyond Longitudinal Study of 2020, which was shifted to 2022 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and had already begun to produce valuable data for researchers.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated the contract for the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study- Kindergarten (ECLS-K:2024), which had already begun to produce useful data for researchers and policymakers after several years of planning.

extracted.value: ED terminated the contract for the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study- Kindergarten (ECLS-K:2024), which had already begun to produce useful data for researchers and policymakers after several years of planning.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated contracts for the National Teacher and Principal Survey, which collects data every two to three years on core topics including teacher and principal preparation, classes taught, school characteristics, and demographics of the teacher and principal labor force—a version of which has been conducted since 1987.

extracted.value: ED terminated contracts for the National Teacher and Principal Survey, which collects data every two to three years on core topics including teacher and principal preparation, classes taught, school characteristics, and demographics of the teacher and principal labor force—a version of which has been conducted since 1987.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED also terminated contracts necessary to the Common Core of Data and the Private School Survey.

extracted.value: ED also terminated contracts necessary to the Common Core of Data and the Private School Survey.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED also terminated the contract for the National Assessment of Adult Education.

extracted.value: ED also terminated the contract for the National Assessment of Adult Education.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated contracts necessary for the Condition of Education, a report produced annually by NCES.

extracted.value: ED terminated contracts necessary for the Condition of Education, a report produced annually by NCES.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated the contracts by which the agency was complying with the public dissemination and performance management requirements of the Education Sciences Reform Act, including the contract for its “DATALAB” web platform and contracts for its What Works Clearinghouse.

extracted.value: ED terminated the contracts by which the agency was complying with the public dissemination and performance management requirements of the Education Sciences Reform Act, including the contract for its “DATALAB” web platform and contracts for its What Works Clearinghouse.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: ED terminated the contract for NCES’s mail center.

extracted.value: ED terminated the contract for NCES’s mail center.

evidence.text: Until I was placed on administrative leave on March 21, 2025, I worked in the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance (NCEE)...

extracted.value: Abigail Doe was placed on administrative leave on March 21, 2025.

evidence.text: Until I was placed on administrative leave on March 21, 2025, I worked in the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance (NCEE)...

extracted.value: She worked at NCEE until that leave.

evidence.text: Through my work for NCEE, I am familiar with the Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) and the What Works Clearinghouse (WWC).

extracted.value: She is familiar with the REL program and What Works Clearinghouse.

evidence.text: The REL program was created by 20 U.S.C. § 9564. There are ten RELs throughout the country.

extracted.value: The REL program was created by 20 U.S.C. § 9564 and has ten RELs.

evidence.text: RELs work in partnership with state and local education departments and school districts through which IES provides three types of services: applied research to meet the needs of our state and local partners; training and technical assistance; and dissemination of evidence-based programs, policies, and practices in user-friendly formats.

extracted.value: RELs provide applied research, training, technical assistance, and dissemination to state/local education departments.

evidence.text: These services are provided through five-year contracts, and a separate contract provides peer review to ensure that the applied research conducted through the RELs is scientifically valid.

extracted.value: REL services are provided through five-year contracts; a separate contract provides peer review.

evidence.text: The topics of REL research are never dictated by IES staff but always come from the local partners on the ground.

extracted.value: Topics of REL research are dictated by local partners.

evidence.text: On February 10, 2025, I attended an emergency meeting with other NCEE staff at which we were told that all of our contracts were being canceled by DOGE except for the REL contracts.

extracted.value: On February 10, 2025, Abigail attended an emergency meeting where she was told all contracts were being canceled by DOGE except REL contracts.

evidence.text: We did not receive copies of the contract termination notices, which caused a lot of confusion about what was going on.

extracted.value: No copies of termination notices were provided.

evidence.text: On February 13, a colleague received an email from the Contracts and Acquisitions Management office informing them that the REL contract they managed was being canceled after all.

extracted.value: On February 13, a colleague received an email from Contracts and Acquisitions Management stating the REL contract was being canceled after all.

evidence.text: The Department posted a press release on its website stating that the REL contracts were canceled as “woke spending.”

extracted.value: A press release on February 13 stated REL contracts were canceled as “woke spending.”

evidence.text: During the February 10 meeting, we were told that the REL contracts would not be terminated, but would be recompeted.

extracted.value: The emergency meeting said REL contracts would not be terminated but would be recompeted.

evidence.text: But the contracts were cancelled, without the initiation of any new bidding process; as such, the RELs’ statutorily-mandated work has come to a halt for the foreseeable future.

extracted.value: Contracts were canceled without a new bidding process; statutorily mandated work was halted.

evidence.text: One REL had done outreach to thousands of school districts in order to find 40 (20 for the experimental condition and 20 for the control group) to test the toolkit as part of the efficacy study, and that study was in the midst of being conducted when the contract was canceled.

extracted.value: Nine of ten RELs had completed toolkits and were conducting efficacy studies when contracts were canceled.

evidence.text: The efficacy studies will never be completed, meaning all the time and money spent to set them up was wasted.

extracted.value: The efficacy studies would never be completed.

evidence.text: The toolkits themselves may never be released, and even if IES releases its rights to the data and the contractors choose to release it, it is harder to stand behind the toolkits’ usability and IES cannot say with any degree of assurance how the toolkits impact student outcomes.

extracted.value: The toolkits may never be released; data may not be released; uncertain impact on student outcomes.

evidence.text: Staff were working on three practice guides that were nearly complete when the contracts were canceled in mid-February. One of the three had already gone through peer review, but the other two had not, and the peer review contract in the Standards and Review Office (SRO) was also canceled.

extracted.value: Staff were working on three practice guides; two had not been peer-reviewed; the peer review contract was canceled.

evidence.text: IES leadership tried to address this gap by allowing the IES staff to conduct internal peer reviews, but then almost everyone received RIF notices and was ordered to stop working as of March 21.

extracted.value: IES leadership attempted internal peer reviews, but staff received RIF notices and stopped as of March 21.

evidence.text: In the five weeks between the termination of the REL contracts and being placed on administrative leave, neither I nor any other NCEE colleague was tasked with re-establishing the REL program.

extracted.value: No one was tasked with re-establishing the REL program.

evidence.text: To my understanding, there is only one staff member left at NCEE.

extracted.value: Only one staff member remained at NCEE after the cancellations.
